(City of Conway, Faulkner County, Arkansas) |sports = Basketball, Baseball, Softball, Cross Country, Track and Field, Golf, Lacrosse, Field Hockey, Soccer, Swimming and Diving, Tennis, Volleyball, Ultimate (unofficial), Intercollegiate Football Division III (starting fall 2013), Women's Lacrosse (starting fall 2013){{cite web|last=Brantley|first=Max|title=Hendrix Ready to Play Some Football|url=http://www.arktimes.com/ArkansasBlog/archives/2011/06/07/hendrix-ready-to-play-some-football|publisher=Arkansas Times|accessdate=8/10/2012}} |colors = Orange and Black {{color box|#E96B10}}{{color box|black}} |mascot = [[Warrior]] |affiliation = [[United Methodist Church]] |website= {{URL|http://www.hendrix.edu}} }} '''Hendrix College''' is a private [[liberal arts college]] located in [[Conway, Arkansas|Conway]], [[Arkansas]]. The student body averages around 1,400 and currently represents forty-three states and fourteen foreign countries. In ''[[US News and World Report]]'s'' America's Best Colleges, Hendrix was ranked in 2011 as one of the top "up and coming" liberal arts colleges. In the 2008 edition Hendrix is ranked 71st in the nation. In 2009, ''[[Forbes]]'' ranked it 81st of [[Forbes Magazine's List of America's Best Colleges|America's Best Colleges]].{{cite news | url = http://www.forbes.com/lists/2009/94/colleges-09_Americas-Best-Colleges_Rank_4.html | title = America's Best Colleges | publisher = Forbes.com | date=5 August 2009}} The college is affiliated with the [[United Methodist Church]]; however, the curriculum is secular and the student body is composed of people from many different religious backgrounds. Hendrix is a member of the [[Associated Colleges of the South]].{{cite web|title=ASCMemberList|url=http://www.colleges.org/institutions.html|publisher=Associated Colleges of the South|accessdate=8/9/2012}} Its current president is Dr. James Timothy Cloyd. Hendrix College is listed in [[Loren Pope]]'s ''[[Colleges That Change Lives]]''. == College history == Hendrix College was founded as a primary school called Central Institute in 1876 at [[Altus, Arkansas]], by Rev. Isham L. Burrow.{{cite book|last=Lester|first=James E.|title=Hendrix College A Centennial History|year=1984|publisher=Hendrix College Centennial Committee|location=Conway, AR|isbn=0914546546|pages=13-14}} In 1881 it was renamed Central Collegiate Institute when secondary and collegiate departments were added.{{cite book|last=Lester|first=James E.|title=Hendrix College A Centennial History|year=1984|publisher=Hendrix College Centennial Committee|location=Conway, AR|isbn=0914546546|pages=14}} The next year the first graduating collegiate class, composed of three women, were awarded "Mistress of English Literature" degrees.{{cite book|last=Lester|first=James E.|title=Hendrix College A Centennial History|year=1984|publisher=Hendrix College Centennial Committee|location=Conway, AR|isbn=0914546546|pages=14}} In 1884, three conferences of the [[Methodist Episcopal Church, South]] purchased the school.{{cite journal|last=Meriwether|first=Robert W.|title=Hendrix College and Its Relationship to Conway and Faulkner County, 1890-1934|journal=Faulkner Facts and Fiddlings|year=1984|volume=XXVI|issue=2|pages=1-45|url=http://www.faulknerhistory.com/articles/Hendrixcollege.htm|accessdate=8/8/2012}} This began the school's relationship with the [[Methodist Episcopal Church, South]] and later [[The Methodist Church (USA)|The Methodist Church]], and [[United Methodist Church]]. The Central Collegiate Institute was renamed Hendrix College in 1889 in honor of Rev. [[Eugene Russell Hendrix]], a presiding bishop over three Arkansas Methodist conferences.{{cite book|last=Lester|first=James|title=Hendrix College A Centennial History|year=1984|publisher=Hendrix College Centennial Committee|location=Conway, AR|isbn=0914546546|pages=30}} This same year, the primary school was discontinued.{{cite book|last=Lester|first=James|title=Hendrix College A Centennial History|year=1984|publisher=Hendrix College Centennial Committee|location=Conway, AR|isbn=0914546546|pages=30}} Hendrix College was initially designated a male college, but as early as 1889, the class catalog allowed for the enrollment of women who were interested in the college's course of study.{{cite journal|last=Meriwether|first=Robert W.|title=Hendrix College and Its Relationship to Conway and Faulkner County, 1890-1934|journal=Faulkner Facts and Fiddlings|year=1984|volume=XXVI|issue=2|pages=1-45|url=http://www.faulknerhistory.com/articles/Hendrixcollege.htm|accessdate=August 6, 2012}} In 1890, after receiving bids from seven other Arkansas towns, Hendrix Board of Trustees chose Conway as the new location for the college.{{cite book|last=Lester|first=James|title=Hendrix College A Centennial History|year=1984|publisher=Hendrix College Centennial Committee|location=Conway, AR|isbn=0914546546|pages=42}} By 1925 the secondary department was discontinued. A bid was accepted in 1929 to merge the college with Henderson-Brown College, a private college in [[Arkadelphia, Arkansas]]. The merger briefly created Hendrix-Henderson College, until two years later when the Board of Trustees removed "Henderson" from the name. {{cite book|last=Lester|first=James|title=Hendrix College A Centennial History|year=1984|publisher=Hendrix College Centennial Committee|location=Conway, AR|isbn=0914546546|pages=120-123}} As a result of this merger, the Hendrix Bull Dogs became the Hendrix Warriors, and the college newspaper, formerly the ''Bull Dog,'' was renamed the ''College Profile.''{{cite journal|last=Meriwether|first=Robert W.|title=Hendrix College and Its Relationship to Conway and Faulkner County, 1890-1934|journal=Faulkner Facts and Fiddlings|year=1984|volume=XXVI|issue=2|pages=1-45|url=http://www.faulknerhistory.com/articles/Hendrixcollege.htm|accessdate=August 6, 2012}} The newly formed college was planning to move the school to [[Little Rock, Arkansas]], but the city of Conway was able to raise $150,000 to keep the school located at Hendrix's campus.{{cite journal|last=Meriwether|first=Robert W.|title=Hendrix College and Its Relationship to Conway and Faulkner County, 1890-1934|journal=Faulkner Facts and Fiddlings|year=1984|volume=XXVI|issue=2|pages=1-45|url=http://www.faulknerhistory.com/articles/Hendrixcollege.htm|accessdate=August 6, 2012}} Two years later the name of the college reverted back to Hendrix College after a short period of being named Trinity College, which was opposed by many students and alumni.{{cite book|last=Lester|first=James|title=Hendrix College A Centennial History|year=1984|publisher=Hendrix College Centennial Committee|location=Conway, AR|isbn=0914546546|pages=125}} The college merged with Galloway Woman’s College in [[Searcy, Arkansas]] in 1933, during the [[Great Depression]]. Hendrix College retained its location and facilities during this merger.[http://www.hendrix.edu/abouthendrix/about.aspx?id=87&ns1_mtid=87&ns1_mtt=1&ns1_mid=17 Hendrix College - History] == Student life == [[Image:HendrixCollegeMainEntrance.JPG|thumb|The main entrance of Hendrix College]] * There are no [[fraternities]] or [[sororities]].{{cite web|title=Hendrix College Student Life|url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/hendrix-college-1099/student-life|publisher=U.S. News|accessdate=8/9/2012}} * Students from 19 foreign countries including Ireland, Korea and The Netherlands.{{cite web|title=International Student Services|url=http://www.hendrix.edu/multicultural/multicultural.aspx?id=5886|accessdate=8/10/2012}} * 16 Rwandan Presidential Scholars, studying at Hendrix through the Rwandan Presidential Scholarship program. Hendrix leads a consortium of 19 private and public institutions of higher education, hosting over 220 Rwandan students.{{cite web|title=Rwanda Presidential Scholars|url=http://www.bridge2rwanda.org/our-work/educating-leaders/rwanda-presidential-scholars/|accessdate=8/10/2012}} * 65 student organizations offer a wide range of student activities, funded by a student activity fee allocated by the Hendrix Student Senate. Social Committee, or SoCo, is the largest student organization and is in charge of planning the larger events on campus. SoCo members are peer-elected each year and represent each hall and class. * The Office of Student Activities plans weekend and Wednesday evening events. Major social events are frequently held in "The Brick Pit" (formerly the "Brick Patio"), an outdoor area in the center of the campus. (Most famous among them is "Shirttails," a freshman dance-off that includes a serenade by the mens' dorms {{cite web|title=Youtube|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nqjLK9jtLqU&feature=related|accessdate=8/9/2012}} ). The campus is located approximately 30 miles from [[Little Rock]], the capital of Arkansas. * The Student Senate is the governing body of the student association. Along with campus-wide elected officers, students elect representatives from each class, residence hall and apartment building.{{cite web|title=Hendrix College Student Senate Constitution|url=http://www.hendrix.edu/uploadedFiles/Student_Life/Student_Activities/Hendrix%20College%20Senate%20Constitution%20and%20Bylaws.pdf|publisher=Hendrix College Student Senate|accessdate=8/9/2012}} * The Hendrix College Student Congress team won Arkansas Student Congress championships in 2004, 2007, 2009, 2010, and 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.hendrix.edu/news/news.aspx?id=44744 |title=Hendrix College | Hendrix selected as Best Delegation |publisher=Hendrix.edu |date=25 November 2009 |accessdate=4 March 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hendrix.edu/news/news.aspx?id=49890 |title=Hendrix College | Hendrix Group Wins 2010 Student Congress |publisher=Hendrix.edu |date=3 November 2010 |accessdate=4 March 2012}} * In 2010, Hendrix was named one of "The Top 50 Schools That Produce Science PhDs" by CBS Moneywatch.com compiled from information by The National Science Foundation.{{cite web|url=http://moneywatch.bnet.com/saving-money/blog/college-solution/top-50-schools-that-produce-science-phds/2954/ |title=Top 50 Schools That Produce Science PhDs - CBS News |publisher=Moneywatch.bnet.com |date=1 September 2010 |accessdate=4 March 2012}} ==Athletics== Hendrix College teams participate as a member of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]]'s [[Division III (NCAA)|Division III]]. The Warriors are a charter member of the [[Southern Athletic Association]] (SAA), starting effectively in the 2012-13 season. Hendrix was formerly a member of the [[Southern Collegiate Athletic Conference]] (SCAC). Men's sports include baseball, basketball, cross country, football, golf, lacrosse, soccer, swimming & diving, tennis and track & field; while women's sports include basketball, cross country, field hockey, golf, lacrosse, soccer, softball, swimming & diving, tennis, track & field and volleyball. == Recognition == ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' lists Hendrix as the #1 “Up-and-coming Liberal Arts College” in its 2009, 2010, and 2011 list of colleges.{{cite web|title=Up-and-Coming Schools|url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/rankings/national-liberal-arts-colleges/up-and-coming|publisher=U.S. News and World Report|accessdate=8/10/2012}} Hendrix is also ranked 80th on the magazine's list of best liberal arts colleges.{{cite web|last=US News|title=Best Colleges 2011|url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/libarts-uc-rank|work=US News|publisher=US News|accessdate=15 September 2010}} The ''Fiske Guide to Colleges'' names Hendrix as one of 44 national "Best Buy" colleges and universities in its 2010 edition.{{cite web|last=Fiske|title=Fiske Guide Announces 2011 Best Buys|url=http://www.fiskeguide.com/?p=55|work=The Fiske Guides|publisher=Sourcebooks, Inc.|accessdate=15 September 2010}} ''[[Forbes]]'' lists Hendrix as ranked #102 on the “America's Best Colleges” for 2010.{{cite news|last=Forbes|title=America's Best Colleges|url=http://www.forbes.com/lists/2010/94/best-colleges-10_Hendrix-College_94182.html|work=Forbes|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=15 September 2010|date=11 August 2010}} The ''[[Princeton Review]]'' lists Hendrix for academic excellence in its 2008 college guide, ''The Best 366 Colleges:'' 11th in the "professors get high marks" category, 11th in the "best classroom experience" category, 16th in the "best college theater" category, and 20th in the "lots of race/class interaction."{{cite book|last=Review|first=Princeton|title=he Best 366 Colleges, 2008 Edition|year=2007|publisher=The Princeton Review}} Its 2008 edition of ''American’s Best Value Colleges'' also lists Hendrix.{{cite book|last=Review|first=Princeton|title=The Princeton Review’s 2008 edition of America’s Best Value Colleges 2008 Edition|year=2007|publisher=Princeton Review}} ''The Best 371 Colleges'' (2010) lists Hendrix 5th for “Easiest Campus to Get Around” and 13th for “Best Athletic Facilities.”{{cite book|last=Review|first=Princeton|title=The Best 371 Colleges, 2010 Edition|year=2009|publisher=Princeton Review}} Hendrix College is featured in Loren Pope's ''[[Colleges That Change Lives]]: 40 Schools that Will Change the Way You Think About Colleges.''{{cite book|last=Pope|first=Loren|title=Colleges that Change Lives: 40 Schools that Will Change the Way You Think About Colleges|year=2006|publisher=Penguin}} The [[Institute of International Education]] has awarded Hendrix with a 2012 [[Andrew Heiskell Award]] for International Exchange Partnerships as project coordinators of the Rwanda Presidential Scholars Program.{{cite web|last=|title=2012 Heiskell Award Winner: International Exchange Partnerships|url=http://www.iie.org/Who-We-Are/IIENetwork-Membership/Heiskell-Awards/International-Exchange-Partnerships/Hendrix-College|work=|publisher=Institute of International Education, Inc.|accessdate=29 January 2012}} == Campus buildings == Since the mid-1990s, the college has been pursuing a master plan for campus construction, developed in consultation with the architectural design firm [[Duany Plater Zyberk & Company|Duany Plater-Zyberk & Co.]] There are 36 buildings on campus, three of which are listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] (NRHP). === Academic and administrative buildings === * '''Admin Houses''': Health services, counseling services. * '''Art Complex''': Art department. * '''Charles D. Morgan Center for Physical Sciences/Acxiom Hall''': Chemistry department, Physics department. * '''Olin C. Bailey Library''' * '''Buhler Hall''': Currently vacant, due to the addition of the Student Life and Technology Center. * '''Donald W. Reynolds Center for Life Sciences''': Biology department, Psychology department. * '''Ellis Hall''': Office of Admissions, Financial Aid, (NRoHP). * '''Fausett Hall''': Office of Administration, English department, Foreign Language departments. * '''Greene Chapel''': School's official chapel, venue for annual Candlelight Carol service. * '''I.T.''': Information technology offices. * '''Morgan Center/John Hugh Reynolds''': Mathematics and Computer Science department, Physics department, Chemistry department. * '''Mills Center''': Cabe Theater, Economics and Business department, Education department, History department, Politics and International Relations department, Sociology and Anthropology department. * '''Bertie Wilson Murphy Building''': Hendrix-Murphy Foundation. * '''Physical Plant''': (Originally built as short-term housing and called “East Hall”) * '''Public Safety''': Mainly deals with security and parking issues. * '''Raney Building''': Religion and Philosophy department. * '''Staples Auditorium''': Large auditorium, also houses Greene Chapel. * '''Trieschmann Building''': Music department, Dance studio, Reves Recital Hall, and Trieschmann gallery. * '''Student Life and Technology Center''': Office of Student Affairs, Social Committee, Master Calendar, cafeteria, the Burrow (student deli), Oathurst Technology Center (computer lab), IT Help Desk, Odyssey, and Career Services. It also contains all student activities and organization offices, the KHDX radio station, the Religious Life Suite, Residence Life offices and the post office. === Residence halls=== *'''The Eco-House''': Co-ed house with an emphasis on environmental sustainability. * '''Apartments on Clifton Street''' * '''Couch Hall''': Co-ed residence hall named after Arkansas entrepreneur [[Harvey Couch]].{{Citation | first = James | last = Lester | author-link = James Lester | title = Hendrix College, A Centennial History | publisher = Hendrix College Centennial Committee | year = 1984 | page = 180 | isbn = 0-914546-54-6}} * '''The Hendrix Corner Apartments''': Apartments located at the intersection of Front Street and Mill Street. (also called the Mill Street Apartments) * '''Front Street Apartments''': Apartments at the intersection of Front Street and Spruce Street. * '''[[Galloway Hall]]''': Female residence hall (NRoHP) named to honor Bishop [[Charles Galloway|Charles Betts Galloway]]{{cite web | last = Stanick | first = Katherine | title = Galloway Female College | work = Encyclopedia of Arkansas History and Culture | date = 10 October 2009 | url = http://www.encyclopediaofarkansas.net/encyclopedia/entry-detail.aspx?entryID=4593# | accessdate = 17 September 2011}} and listed on the U.S. [[National Register of Historic Places]]{{NRISref|version=2010a}} * '''Hardin Hall''': Male residence hall whose namesake, G.C. Hardin, was a 1905 graduate.{{Citation | first = James | last = Lester | author-link = James Lester | title = Hendrix College, A Centennial History | publisher = Hendrix College Centennial Committee | year = 1984 | page = 212 | isbn = 0-914546-54-6}} * '''Huntington Apartments''': College-owned apartments located on Clifton Street. * '''Martin Hall''': Male residence hall (NRoHP) named in honor of Conway civic leader Capt. W. W. Martin, who worked to bring Hendrix to Conway {{Citation | first = James | last = Lester | author-link = James Lester | title = Hendrix College, A Centennial History | publisher = Hendrix College Centennial Committee | year = 1984 | page = 94 | isbn = 0-914546-54-6}} * '''The Quad''': Four co-ed residence houses: Cook, Dickinson, McCreight, and Browne. * '''Brown House and Stella Boyle Smith House (commonly Smith House)''': Two co-ed residential houses close to The Quad. * '''Language House''': Single-language themed co-ed house. Rotates annually among French, German, and Spanish. * '''Raney Hall''': Female residence hall named in 1960 for Alton B. Raney, a former trustee of the college. * '''Veasey Hall''': Female residence hall named to honor former trustee Ruth Veasey.{{Citation | first = James | last = Lester | author-link = James Lester | title = Hendrix College, A Centennial History | publisher = Hendrix College Centennial Committee | year = 1984 | page = 214 | isbn = 0-914546-54-6}} * '''The Village Apartments''' Two mixed-use buildings with commercial space on the ground floors and student apartments on the upper floors, part of the Village at Hendrix, a New Urban-style housing development project.{{cite web|last=Dickerson|first=Rachel Parker|title=Community leaders discuss "town-gown relations"|url=http://thecabin.net/news/local/2009-10-05/community-leaders-discuss-%E2%80%98town-gown-relations%E2%80%99#.UCVWffaPX_M|publisher=The Log Cabin Democrat|accessdate=8/10/2012}} === Recreational buildings === * '''Mabee Center''': Basketball court, volleyball court, racquetball courts, indoor tennis courts, fitness room. * '''Wellness and Athletics Center''': Houses the Physical Education department, basketball courts, a swimming pool, a free weights room, lacrosse field, an indoor track, a soccer field, and a baseball field. The underpass nearby, which connects the building to the main campus and runs under Harkrider Street, is the location of an interactive art exhibit by [[Christopher Janney]] titled ''Harmonic Fugue''.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Harmonic Fugue – Conway, AR | work = Urban Musical Instruments | publisher = Janney Sound | date = | url = http://janneysound.com/urban-musical-instruments/harmonic-fugue/ | format = | doi = | accessdate = 30 March 2012}} == Notable alumni and faculty== * [[Ashlie Atkinson]]: film, television, and stage actress * [[Douglas Blackmon]]: journalist and bureau chief with the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''; winner of the [[Pulitzer Prize]] in 2009 for his book ''[[Slavery by Another Name: The Re-Enslavement of Black Americans from the Civil War to World War II]]'', adapted as a PBS documentary in 2012, available online.{{cite web|title=Slavery By Another Name|url=http://www.slaverybyanothername.com/|accessdate=8/9/2012}} {{cite web|title=Slavery by Another Name PBS|url=http://www.pbs.org/tpt/slavery-by-another-name/|publisher=PBS|accessdate=8/9/2012}} * [[Sarah Caldwell]]: notable [[opera]] conductor;
